response:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<Integer> it = list.iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
i++;
System.out.println(it.next());
}
<<<explanation>>>: In a for-each loop, the value of the loop variable is not copied from the original list, but rather a new object is created for each iteration of the loop and the value of the next element in the list is returned by the iterator. Therefore, using `i++` inside the loop will not affect the value of the loop variable in the next iteration. Instead, you can use `it.next()` to get the value of the next element in the list and assign it to the loop variable.
